item.title: Tidying Excel cash flow spreadsheets using R
item.description: Below is a typical cash flow statement for 1 year of performance, broken down by month. This does not fit the “tidy” data standards, but is incredibly common in the Financial world. Don’t worry too much about how hard this is to see, I’ll zoom in on relevant features as we go along. But do notice how columns C through Z are the months, and the left two columns represent main and sub-headers for the cash flow…

item.title: Writing a paper with RStudio
item.description: This semester I had to write a paper for my Financial Econometrics class. My topic was on analyzing the volatility of Bitcoin using GARCH modeling. I’m not particularly interested in Bitcoin, but with all the recent news around it, and with its highly volatile characteristics, I figured it would be a good candidate for analysis. I did the analysis in R, but I wanted to take it a step further. Could I write the entire paper in R and RStudio in a fairly professional format?

item.title: Financial Numerical Methods - Part 1

At first, I thought this wasn’t going to be possible, as this is a recursive type of formula where the next value relies on the previous…

item.title: Which RStudio blog posts “pleased” Hadley? A tidytext + web scraping analysis
item.description: Awhile back, I saw a conversation on twitter about how Hadley uses the word “pleased” very often when introducing a new blog post (I couldn’t seem to find this tweet anymore. Can anyone help?). Out of curiousity, and to flex my R web scraping muscles a bit, I’ve decided to analyze the 240+ blog posts that RStudio has put out since 2011. This post will do a few things: Spoiler alert: Hadley uses “pleased”…

item.title: RStudio and Shiny Servers with AWS - Part 1
item.description: After realizing how fast I can burn through my free 25 hours on shinyapps.io, I decided to repurpose my RStudio Server to also work with Shiny Server. Here’s my new setup: In case I ever have to go through this madness again, or if anyone else wants to, I’ve compiled some step by step notes on the…

item.title: Amazon RDS + R
item.description: Welcome to my first post! To start things off at Data Insights, I’m going to show you how to connect to an AWS RDS instance from R. For those of you who don’t know, RDS is an easy way to create a database in the cloud. In this post, I won’t be showing you how to setup an RDS instance, but I will show you how to connect to it if you have one running.
